creator: smh1008@cus.cam.ac.uk
text:
When attempting to run the standard unmodified Tomcat 3.2.1 distribution in 
Redhat 7.1 (Blackdown JDK1.3 JVM) with the startup.sh script, I encounter the 
following messages:-

Guessing TOMCAT_HOME from tomcat.sh to bin/..
Setting TOMCAT_HOME to bin/..
Using classpath: 
bin/../lib/ant.jar:bin/../lib/jasper.jar:bin/../lib/jaxp.jar:bin/../lib/parser.jar:bin/../lib/servlet.jar:bin/../lib/test:bin/../lib/webserver.jar:/usr/local/biojava/biojava.jar:/usr/local/biojava/xerces.jar:/usr/local/biojava/bytecode.jar:.[

The script returns control to me at this point and no further messages are 
generated from Tomcat.  The standard stuff in the webapps folder are not 
served.

Checks on netstat -a show ports 8007 and 8080 to be unallocated.  Several 
processes are started by the script (typically 6-7).  As expected bin/shutdown 
does not stop Tomcat (unable to connect to 8007).

When TOMCAT_OPTS are set to -Xint to run in interpreted mode only, Tomcat runs 
OK.

The problem does NOT go away when run with the IBM Java2 JVM (usually two 
processes started only).  Moving to SMP Linux kernel 2.4.3 does NOT prevent 
the problem.  Going to Tomcat 3.3 milestone 2 does NOT prevent the problem.  
Going to Tomcat 4.0 beta 3 DOES solve it.

Configuration
=============
Linux version 2.4.2-2smp (root@porky.devel.redhat.com) (gcc version 2.96 
20000731 (Red Hat Linux 7.1 2.96-79)) #1 SMP Sun Apr 8 20:21:34 EDT 2001
Blackdown Java 1.3.0.
Dual Celeron on GA-6BXD. 256MB RAM.

I don't know if its a Tomcat problem or a JVM problem (since it is 
reproducible on two JVMs).

creator: smh1008@cus.cam.ac.uk
text:
I have investigated the problem further and it is probably NOT a Tomcat bug but 
some peculiar problem with various JVMs and Redhat 7.1.  The hangs occur in 
rtsuspend and are very similar to a report by one of the Blackdown developers 
in Dec 2000.

The most reliable way I found of working round it was to reboot with a 
uniprocessor kernel and running with Sun JVM 1.3.0_02 with the -classic flag 
set but that defeats the whole purpose of having an SMP machine.
